titleStmt.title: The ancient practical laws of England, compared with the laws now practised, to the great grievance of the free-born subject; by an ancient practising barrister at law, who for the greatest part of seventeen years last past, hath been a prisoner of the King's-Bench, Fleet, and other prisons, unjustly confined under undue practices, mentioned in eight of the ten paragraphs underwritten.

The ancient practical laws of England, compared with the laws now practised, to the great grievance of the free-born subject; by an ancient practising barrister at law, who for the greatest part of seventeen years last past, hath been a prisoner of the King's-Bench, Fleet, and other prisons, unjustly confined under undue practices, mentioned in eight of the ten paragraphs underwritten.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in the British Library.
